Article.ArticleTitle: Single-layer graphene membranes by crack-free transfer for gas mixture separation.

AbstractText: The single-layer graphene film, when incorporated with molecular-sized pores, is predicted to be the ultimate membrane. However, the major bottlenecks have been the crack-free transfer of large-area graphene on a porous support, and the incorporation of molecular-sized nanopores. Herein, we report a nanoporous-carbon-assisted transfer technique, yielding a relatively large area (1 mm<sup>2</sup>), crack-free, suspended graphene film. Gas-sieving (H<sub>2</sub>/CH<sub>4</sub> selectivity up to 25) is observed from the intrinsic defects generated during the chemical-vapor deposition of graphene. Despite the ultralow porosity of 0.025%, an attractive H<sub>2</sub> permeance (up to 4.1 × 10<sup>-7</sup> mol m<sup>-2</sup> s<sup>-1</sup> Pa<sup>-1</sup>) is observed. Finally, we report ozone functionalization-based etching and pore-modification chemistry to etch hydrogen-selective pores, and to shrink the pore-size, improving H<sub>2</sub> permeance (up to 300%) and H<sub>2</sub>/CH<sub>4</sub> selectivity (up to 150%). Overall, the scalable transfer, etching, and functionalization methods developed herein are expected to bring nanoporous graphene membranes a step closer to reality.
